title: Removing :single_mr_diff_view and :diffs_batch_load feature flags
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## What

Remove the `:single_mr_diff_view` feature flag ...
Remove the `:diffs_batch_load` feature flag ...


## Owners

- Team: Create: Source Code Frontend
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_source-code`
- Best individual to reach out to: @thomasrandolph (or @andr3)

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

Faster MR load times since we're not loading both inline and parallel data anymore (with ff on).

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

Any MR functionality broken—especially after toggling between inline or parallel—, namely:

- comments
- MR Reviews
- Suggestions


### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

At the stage of setting this to default true, is basically monitoring bugs being created, especially ~customer ones since it'll be enabled on gitlab.com before it: 

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?scope=all&utf8=%E2%9C%93&state=opened&label_name[]=merge%20requests&label_name[]=bug

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups


## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [x] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] After Feature Flag has run for at least 24hrs in production with no reported problems, update the feature flag to default to true and add changelog entry
- [x] On the following Release, remove feature flag code
- [ ] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Come up with design for button to schedule manual build steps for immediate execution (once prior steps pass)
description:
Effort in preparation of the [build track](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/#build-track) for issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/16509

### Weighting rubric

| Size     | Score | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
|----------|-------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--|--|--|--|--|--|--|--|
| Trivial  | 1     | Mostly small to medium UI changes, smaller UX improvements, without unanswered questions. UX may need to stay involved with the issue but might not have to do work.                                                                                                                                                                      |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Small    | 2     | Simple UI or UX change where we understand all of the requirements, but may need to find solutions to known questions/problems.                                                                                                                                                                                                           |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Medium   | 3     | A medium change (lots of UI or UX changes/improvements required). Multiple pages are involved, we're starting to design/redesign small flows. Some unknown questions may arise during the work.                                                                                                                                           |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Large    | 5     | A complicated change where other team members will need to be involved. Spans across multiple pages, we're working on medium-sized flows. There are significant open questions that need to be answered.                                                                                                                                  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Huge     | 8     | A complex change that spans across large flows and may require input from other designers. This is the largest flow design/redesign that we would take on in a single milestone.                                                                                                                                                          |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |
| Gigantic | 13    | A significant change that spans across multiple flows and that would require significant input from others (teams, team members, user feedback) and there are many unknown unknowns. It's unlikely we would commit to this in a milestone, and the preference would be to further clarify requirements and/or break in to smaller issues. |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |  |

title: Raise user-limit on DAG relationships
description:
### Problem to solve

We currently have a maximum of 10 on dependencies for a DAG, but there are common workflows where a higher limit than this is needed. We need to determine what the system protection limit is and set the maximum to that number rather than a number that users are bumping into.

We also want to provide a (potentially unsupported) very high limit for self-managed instance administrators who choose to do so.

See also infrastructure issue at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/infrastructure/-/issues/7541

Current limitations are documented at https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/yaml/README.html#requirements-and-limitations

**Note that majority of the efforts of this issue have been merged, please refer to: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197886#note_394376627 for the work remaining**

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals (contributes to our vision?) -->

### Proposal

1. Update the DAG limit for normal operation to 50 users, and apply this feature flag in production.
2. Set a "crazy" limit feature flag that allows for setting the limit to something like 1000, for instance administrators at their own risk. We have users who are running things at this level, so it isn't a footgun, but it is an untested configuration (officially) and helps teams who are doing so not to source patch GitLab. The actual number here is still TBD.

### Permissions and Security

None new

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html
Add all known Documentation Requirements here, per https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html#documentation-requirements
If this feature requires changing permissions, this document https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html must be updated accordingly. -->

title: Private Commit Emails should not be choosable for Notifications or profile addresses
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Private commit emails (as proposed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/issues/43521) can be chosen for Notifications, which leads to GitLab trying to send Emails to these non-existing addresses.

They can also be chosen for the public profile address in Profile -> Public email, which is not really useful either.

### Relevant Documentation

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/profile/index.html#private-commit-email

### Steps to reproduce

Go to Profile or Notifications and try to change your mail to these non-existing addresses.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The private commit emails are choosable

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The private commit emails are not choosable (grayed out in the list or not there at all)

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

title: Project-level Exportable Security Reports MVC
description:
### Problem to solve

Users are unable to effectively share the results of our security reports outside GitLab.  They need to provide these reports to their managers, compliance teams, and sometimes their clients. They need a human readable format that can be printed or sent via email.

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

***NOTE***: This should be built on top of the new standalone vulnerability object model.

For an MVC, we will add functionality enabling the user to download a Project's security report in a CSV format. This includes:

* A button to download the report from the Project-level Security Dashboard
* Dismissible popover calling attention to the new functionality containing a link to the [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/197111) for leaving feedback (pointed to the button with a link to the feedback issue for first time view (does not reappear after dismissed))
* Generated CSV file is dynamically named such that it is easily recognizable and distinguishable from other reports.  For example: "project-name_2020-01-01T14:05.csv"

**Suggested CSV Headers:**
This is not all data available in the [JSON security reports](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/index.html#reports-json-format) but it should be the relevant information for such a report. First part is the suggested header field name, item in parentheses is the parameter name in the JSON schema from which to pull this data:

*  Scanner Type ("category”)
*  Scanner Name (“scanner”: {”name”})
*  Vulnerability ("name”)
*  Details (“description”)
*  Additional Info (“message”)
*  Severity (“severity”)
*  CVE (“cve”)
*  Status (not from JSON; this is vuln state like 'Confirmed', 'Dismissed', etc.)

### Testing

<!-- What risks does this change pose? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing? See the test engineering process for further help: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/ -->

TBD

### Documentation

Document the new functionality, being sure to clearly call out:
1.  This is currently for Project-level Security Dashboards only
1.  Report is a CSV containing relevant data for ALL vulnerabilities present in default branch; applying visual filters on the Security Dashboard will not yet filter corresponding vulnerabilities from the report.
1.  Helpful screenshots, as appropriate

Suggested location: update to existing https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/security_dashboard/#project-security-dashboard

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

<!-- Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this. -->

We have at least one customer that can take our report export and use it to satisfy a request from an internal team or one of their clients.

### What is the type of buyer? 

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

cc @matt_wilson @chloe @cbazan @plafoucriere @stkerr @NicoleSchwartz

title: Move issue/epic hierarchy items to a tool tip
description:

### Intended users

The intended user is anyone who uses the epic trees. I think these are the most relevant folks:

title: Package Files file_type may be an irrelevant column/attribute
description:
## Background

`file_type` in `packages_package_files` is not seemingly being used anywhere (all values are `NULL` on production)

```ruby
  create_table "packages_package_files", force: :cascade do |t|
    t.bigint "package_id", null: false
    t.datetime_with_timezone "created_at", null: false
    t.datetime_with_timezone "updated_at", null: false
    t.bigint "size"
    t.integer "file_type"
    t.integer "file_store"
    t.binary "file_md5"
    t.binary "file_sha1"
    t.string "file_name", null: false
    t.text "file", null: false
    t.index ["package_id", "file_name"], name: "index_packages_package_files_on_package_id_and_file_name"
  end
```

It is an integer type, which I read as meaning perhaps the original intent was for it to be an enum, but it is not currently being used for that. There was some code in the Maven API specs that was trying to use it to look up a file by format (for example, `jar`, `xml`, `tgz`, etc...), but the code was not actually doing anything so it was removed.

## Proposal

The column should be removed.

## Reference

[Developer docs on removing a column](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/what_requires_downtime.html#dropping-columns)

title: [QA] Replace all BUG_IN_CODE comments with type: :bug
description:
## Summary

Our current [quarantining process](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/guidelines/debugging-qa-test-failures/#quarantining-tests) dictates that we add a comment to our ruby code using

```ruby
# BUG_IN_CODE
```

We should change this to use the new [quarantine message](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22641) hash. 

## Improvements

### Before
```ruby
# BUG_IN_CODE
it 'is quarantined', quarantine: 'https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/12345'
  ...
end
```

### After
```ruby
it 'is quarantined', quarantine: { issue: 'https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/12345', type: :bug }
  ...
end
```

## Risks

Line length might present a problem, but I don't think we should keep a 80 char hard limit.

## Involved components

- qa/qa/specs/helpers/quarantine.rb
- All specs that contain `BUG_IN_CODE`

## Optional: Intended side effects

We will be able to pull reporting on `example.metadata[:quarantine][:type]` and sort on bugs.

title: Suggestions don't render properly after submitting

title: Only one CA certificate is loaded for smart card authentication
description:
### Summary
If multiple certificates are present in the file specified in GitLab.rb gitlab_rails['smartcard_ca_file'], only one certificate is loaded. This appears to prevent successful smart card authentication for customers where multiple root CAs or intermediate certificates are needed.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Configure a standalone gitlab instance for smart card authentication
2. Use a file with multiple certificates as the ca file specified in gitlab_rails['smartcard_ca_file']
3. Attempt to log in using smart card authentication

### Example Project
@SteveTerhar can suggest a customer who can work with us on this.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
Users who attempt to authenticate are redirected to the login page and presented with a "Failed to signing using smartcard authentication" alert message.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
The system should perform a match on e-mail and log the user into the correct GitLab account.

### Possible fixes
Because the store function in smartcard/base.rb calls store.add_cert, only one cert in the smartcard_ca_file is loaded. By changing that call to store.add_file we were able to load multiple certs and log in successfully. 

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/lib/gitlab/auth/smartcard/base.rb#L15

Note: If we use add_file and include intermediate certificates in the file, I believe the intermediate certs would  be treated like root certs and trusted without any verification. We would have to validate that this wouldn't introduce a vulnerability.

epic.title: Smart Card Authentication for the Public Sector

title: Track usage of merge request file header buttons
description:
Originally from the discussion in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/31300#note_255205324

We want to understand how often people use each of the file header buttons when viewing a merge request's changes. To answer questions such as “what is the percentage of visits to the 'Changes' tab of merge requests where people use the 'Edit file' button?”

1. Copy file path
1. Toggle comments for this file
1. Edit file
1. Show full file
1. View file @ SHA
1. Review app link

![image](/uploads/64c69dcacac79acd58d02642575f8526/image.png)

Perhaps we can implement FE event tracking for this: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/event_tracking/frontend.html

title: Migrate package list to vue-router approach
description:
As seen in the the Container Registry it would be beneficial to migrate the package list and details from two separate pages served by rails to two pages but handled by `vue-router` and javascript.

Benefits:

* Only as part of the page needs to reload when navigating
* Snappier transition from the list to details and vice-versa
* Increased performances because we can fully leverage the cache coming from graphql
* Consistency in the package codebase
* If we decide to peruse page transition they could be added effortlessly

### Testing & Availability

Please trigger the `package-and-qa` job in this MR to test all works as expected with existing package managers at the end to end level

title: Diff batch loads overwrites previous diff files
description:
When diff batch loading has to load an extra page it will overwrite the data that previously been set with the new data that has loaded.

From what I can see it comes down to https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/store/utils.js#L220 which says it combines the diff files but doesn't return the previous files, it instead returns the new files passed in. Which in the case of diff batch is the latest page.

/cc @andr3 @thomasrandolph @jboyson

title: Forward deployments - Drop previous builds explicitely
description:
This is a follow-up of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/25276.

There's an improvement that can be made, from a performance point of view. More details in [this MR comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22959#note_273010712).

---

When a new deployment gets deployed, some other older deployments can still exist (being in `created` or `pending` state). These older deployments, now being useless, will go through the `RegisterJobService` which will be taxing performance-wise for nothing.

The goal here is to drop older builds (in an async worker) when a deployment succeeds.

title: Track paid sign up flow
description:
We need to track the beginning and the end of the new paid sign up flow in SnowPlow.
When a user successfully signs up, we also want to attach information about the chosen plan and the amount of users.

title: Group and Instance Security Dashboards hit the vulnerabilities summary endpoint without using the data
description:
The Group and Instance Security Dashboards hit the vulnerability summary endpoint, even though they're not using the data from it.

![Screenshot_from_2020-01-17_11-14-04](/uploads/29649957dd72e050ebaee376843d0ee3/Screenshot_from_2020-01-17_11-14-04.png)

That data is only used in the *Project* Security Dashboard, and is used to display this:

![Screenshot_from_2020-01-17_11-05-20](/uploads/bb6b6db7a1ac4a9b94d69283b489b347/Screenshot_from_2020-01-17_11-05-20.png)

The fix is to simply not pass the summary endpoint to the Group/Instance Security Dashboards.

The Pipeline Security Dashboard already correctly does not hit the endpoint.

title: Discovery: bot member for Suggested Solution (was: Auto Remediation)
description:
### Problem to solve

In the auto-remediation [MVC user research](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1OtLhQRtuLbL7orKMFKXnOCuKLuGijqq8aR6XbhZvHjc/edit#slide=id.g6c2267be5e_0_820) (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36500), we found users are not comfortable with being the author of the `auto-created` merge request. There isn't currently a bot or neutral member/user we could use as an alternative.

:film_projector: [view issue kickoff: context, ideation, and questions review](https://youtu.be/9kiZeWKuCOk)

### Intended users

* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->

### Further details

Based on an MVC proposal for a bot (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36500#note_260858531), this discovery looked into the 1) engineering/implementation requirements, 2) security concerns using a `bot` member, 3) UX with using `bot`.

### Proposal

Consider adding a "bot" user to Ultimate tier instance, called `GitLab-Security-Bot`. This user would be the author of the auto-created merge requests.

| **Bot overview**  | 
| ------ | 
| ![bot_profile](/uploads/8bb331eee9fdbc71856ca5ad8b9572b0/bot_profile.png) | 

Use case for auto-remediation https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36500:

| **When activating feature:** user that enables the feature in the configuration section and the `auto-created MR` authored by `GitLab Vulnerability Bot` (instance user account). The feature is opt-in by default, once container and/or dependency scanning are configured  | 
| ------ | 
| ![flow](/uploads/2a85ad09ce2af12d59d45189eec307d4/flow.png) | 

 
##### Discovery review and findings:

* Learn about our existing “bots” functionality `GitLab Support Bot (Service Desk)` and/or `GitLab Alert Bot` 
     * How are they created?
          * https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/10159 - Bot is added on instance-level. It's `User`. From the backend side of things bot can be called by `User.security_bot`. It creates a `User` entity in the database. Bot isn't a member of any project, it is visible only from Users tab in the Admin panel. Such Bot doesn’t take a seat in the License plan. Bot has a User profile, its username can be used in queries by MR’s author name.
     * Are they out of the box?
          * Adding a new bot is quite simple: add new bot to ee/app/models/ee/user_bot_type_enums.rb and follow example for [Alert bot](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/10460/diffs) 
     * How do they work for saas vs on-premise?
          * It works in the same manner.
     * Are the current bots visible members?
          * Yes, for example: `support bot` is visible in the list and the functionality is shown like others, but the user is unable to take actions (goes to 404 page when executed). issue created: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/208793. For the `GitLab Security Bot` we can display the user to surface documentation (actions not visible in UI)
     * How we can add Bot as an MR author?
          * How to assign Bot as an author of MR?
               * Proposed workflow:
                   * Pipeline is successfully finished.
                   * We check if available solutions are available on the backend.
                   * If there are solutions available, we create an MR with the help of `VulnerabilityFeedback::CreateService` and we put security_bot as an author of the MR. (now this service use current user as an author)
               * We can reuse this code https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/197808d37204cc16886e3404e47205555a24335c/ee/app/services/vulnerability_feedback/create_service.rb#L75 to create an MR automatically. We just need to change `current_user` to `bot`.
     * What might we be able to reuse?
     * How do make sure the extra member doesn't add a seat?
          * These bots ain't members, they are "users" on instance level and are operated from inside of GitLab. That means that we can use those bots for any projects. 
* For the use case of auto-remediation MVC:
     * Can we have this bot as a member that’s out of the box? Consider UX when the member is deactivated and the relationship with the opt-in of `auto-create merge request`
     * UX for findability and discovery of the bot
     * Bot member profile page activity - what/when activity will be shown
     * Identify permissions: who can setup/deactivate feature/bot? Is the bot member a developer?
* What are the security concerns?
     * Will sync with our appsec team with proposed prototype to review and analyze for security issues
* Learn about any use cases that may follow

##### other considerations:
* Have a link to the Bot's documentation page in the bot's profile that explains the account and how to manage it and what it does
* For opened merge request, having it automatically assigned could be helpful and/or that aligns to an orgs workflow
* Add activity or note that "This MR was generated automatically by GitLab" or similar to bot action occurs 
* If we have built-in user accounts, these accounts should have something more than a gravatar and a "Bot" name, there should be some design treatment that clearly denotes this account as a system account.

##### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

* In testing our MVC: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36500, we found users said they would create a new member to `auto-create the merge requests`. Does the user use the `GitLab-Security-Bot` instead?
* Does the user understand the bot is a member and understands it's role (author of merge request)?
* Does the user know how to setup the feature? 

##### What is the type of buyer? 
~"GitLab Ultimate" 


# Discovery Conclusion

**Discovery outcome:** UX/Engineering recommends the [proposed solution](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197349#proposal) to introduce a `GitLab-Security-Bot` user in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36500. 

### Engineering notes

##### How to create a bot?
Adding a new bot is quite simple: you need to add bot to bots_hash and create a class method for User model. Example of adding Alert bot: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/10460/diffs 

##### Is Bot a User?
Yes, from the code bot can be called by `User.security_bot`. It creates a User entity in the database. Bot isn't a member of any project, it is visible only from Users tab in the Admin panel. Such Bot doesn’t take a seat in License plan. Bot has a User profile, its username can be used in queries by MR’s author name.

##### How to assign Bot as an author of MR?
Proposed workflow:
Pipeline is successfully finished.
We check if available solutions are available on the backend.
If there are solutions available, we create an MR with the help of VulnerabilityFeedback::CreateService and we put security_bot as an author of the MR. (now this service use current user as an author)
We can reuse this code https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/197808d37204cc16886e3404e47205555a24335c/ee/app/services/vulnerability_feedback/create_service.rb#L75 to create an MR automatically. We just need to change `current_user` to `bot`.

### UX notes

##### Ongoing and next step efforts:
* Displaying projects that https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210519 is configured in the profile. This is to help the user understand what projects are affected by the system bot. (since the profile will span across different projects)
* UX bug: removing front-end actions available to bots in admin > user, related issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/195309. The `Security Bot` will be seen in the admin 
* Work closely with the technical writing team to ensure clear documentation. Additionally, evaluate as new tasks are added to the bot.
* In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/36503 and any other system tasks the bot may adopt: evaluate with app sec team to ensure alignment and identify security concerns.
* Look into creating a custom bot emoji to reinforce it’s a bot (key UXR question: do users understand this is a system, not their org user)
* Visual design: 1)  create an avatar for the security bot, and 2) align profile with other bots for consistency and better communication to the user that it’s a system bot (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/210523). Example: that https://gitlab.com/support-bot does not include links to documentation or visually anything to distinguish it as a system bot. 

##### User research questions:
* What is the user’s perception of the bot?
* Does the user understand that the user is a GitLab system feature?
* If the user wants to learn more, what do they do?
* Is the documentation accessible and clear?

title: Unexpected behavior around the lastCommitMsg and isCompact
description:
From @cwoolley-gitlab's [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/21067#note_272876171) on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/21067:

I'm seeing some unexpected behavior after this commit around the `lastCommitMsg` and `isCompact`. This occurs on this commit (`bc303216fdf`) but not on the previous commit (`c8af18ef2a6`)

## To reproduce:

1. Open the Web IDE for some repo on which you have permission to commit to master.
1. Make sure your window is taller than `MAX_WINDOW_HEIGHT_COMPACT = 750`
1. Modify a file
1. Click the "commit" tab in the left sidebar.
1. (if you are on the previous commit) stage the change.
1. Enter a commit message
1. Select "Commit to **master** branch"
1. Click "Commit"
1. You will return to the "Edit" tab (commit message is gone, commit is successful)
1. You will temporarily see a message like "Successful commit. All changes are committed...Your changes have been committed. Commit 8c0fb422 with 1 additions, 1 deletions." (this is the `lastCommitMsg`.
1. Then the message disappears

## Expected

1. After the `lastCommitMsg` disappears, the commit area slides down, and only shows a disabled "Commit" button and message "0 unstaged and 0 staged changes"

## Actual

1. After the `lastCommitMsg` disappears, the un-compact commit form reappears, with the commit message text area, master/branch radio buttons, and "Stage & Commit"/"Collapse" buttons.

FYI, I found this while trying to rebase/reconcile these changes with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/21010#note_272731415.

Also, as a heads up, I see inconsistent behavior when exploring this in local GDK. Sometimes, when clicking the commit tab after making a change, the commit form is compact when it shouldn't be. But I've never been able to reproduce it while debugging to figure out why.

title: Update an existing Epic to be Confidential
description:
### Problem to solve

> As a User of Confidential Issues,
> I need to organize them into an Epic that is also confidential,
> So that I can easily organize shared work and provide the proper context and information at the Epic level

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)

title: Value Stream Analytics - Move type of work charts to separate module
description:
## Summary

This issue is part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2434 and covers separating the Value Stream Analytics 'Type of work' charts into a separate module. This follows the pattern used for Productivity Analytics.

* [x] Expose a single component that will be rendered in the `base.vue` component
* [x] Move [vuex state actions/mutations into separate modules]
* [x] Move relevant tests into a new files
* [x] Add additional tests for each component

## Improvements

As the features in Value Stream Analytics have grown, we have continued to add more endpoints, components and functionality. We are now in a position where it makes sense to split some of the features into separate modules, particularly to help reduce the complexity of the `analytics/cycle_analytics/components/base.vue` component and the relevant vuex state.

## Risks
* Merge conflicts while changes are happening

title: Design view: make transitions between zoom states smoother
description:
### Problem to solve

Raised by @andr3 (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22148#note_269881183), for a better UX, we should investigate making the transitions between zoom states smoother.

Currently, when zooming in/out, you are "snapped" to the zoom state. Adding a subtle CSS transition could improve the experience of this.

### Intended users

All users of Design Management

### Proposal

Something like the following could suffice:

```scss
transition: 0.5s;
transition-property: width, height;
```

title: Design view: better resizing support for zoomed-in designs
description:
### Problem to solve

The current experience when zooming in on a design is as follows:

1. Load page
2. Zoom in on image
3. Click `reset` _or_ zoom all the way out

This behaves as expected. However, problems arise when the window is resized after zooming:

1. Load page
2. Zoom in on image
3. Resize page
4. Click `reset` _or_ zoom all the way out

**Result**:

- The image dimensions are whatever they were in Step 1 (which are either too big or small for the current window size)

**Expected**:

- The image dimensions are reset such that they fit the current window dimensions

### Intended users

All users of design management

### Testing

Tests should be included to test this feature.

### Links / references

- Original feature issue => #13217 
- Comment where this issue was originally surfaced => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22863#note_271168923

title: Design view: add ability to explore a zoomed-in design via click-and-drag
description:
### Problem to solve

Currently, when a user is zoomed in on an image within the Design view, they are able to navigate around the image via mouse's scrollwheel and/or the browser scrollbars.

An improvement to this UX could be to give users the ability to click-and-drag to move around the image.

### Intended users

All users of Design Management

### Proposal

Clicking on an image currently places an annotation pin. The solution needs to be able to support this on both desktop and mobile.

A combination of `mousedown` and `mouseup` on desktop, and `touchstart`, `touchend` and `touchmove` on mobile will be required.

### [Video of proposal from @jareko](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/197324#note_291068340)

### Design Specification

* Original spec from #13217 (by @jareko) [can be found here](https://gitlab-org.gitlab.io/gitlab-design/hosted/jarek/gitlab-13217-design-view-zoom-spec-previews/#artboard0)

### Documentation

Documentation will need to be updated to highlight this capability

### Testing

Because of the additional event listeners required, performance must be a consideration for the implementation of this feature.

### Links / references

- Original discussion around this feature discussed in => #13217

title: Time period for usage activity by stage in usage data (Step 1)
description:
<!-- Please complete the template below as best as you can. Make sure to check if this issue has already been raised by someone else first to avoid duplication. 

For each section below, please add screenshots or links or anything that may help visual learners understand the problem better, even if this takes you an extra minute or two this is a great help to some folks.

https://www.learning-styles-online.com/style/visual-spatial/

-->
Parent Issue : https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/telemetry/issues/308
### Problem

Usage ping counters only count unique users over all-time.

### Proposal

Enhance the counters to count unique users over a rolling 28 day period for the counts in usage_activity_by_stage.
This is needed to calculate [AMAU](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/metrics/#actions-monthly-active-users-amau).

This [issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/telemetry/issues/40) has some discussion on this topic

### Outcome
Calculate AMAU & SMAU



### Next steps (if any)

title: Linked issues no longer shows implicit mention of related issues but shows the count

title: Geo: Spike Self-Service Framework with Package Files
description:
## Goal

* Create a new PackageFile
* See that the secondary attempted to request the PackageFile
* See the PackageFileRegistry exists but failed

This cuts across the first implementation issues of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2346:

* gitlab#118743
* gitlab#118745
* gitlab#118749
* gitlab#118747

### Not promised

* If a PackageFile is deleted, Geo may not send an event yet
* Existing PackageFiles are not synced
* Documentation
* All necessary tests
* Downloading a PackageFile may not work yet (Uploading to be implemented in another iteration)

### Promised

* Feature flagged with `geo_self_service_framework`
* General architecture and naming
* It is clear where to add a Delete event
* It is clear where to add a new Blob Type so that it would also be synced upon creation

title: The Board List Issuable sidebar and board list settings overlap when both are opened
description:
#### Problem to solve

When Board List Issuable sidebar is open and a user opens a drawer- the two overlap.

![2020-01-16_16.42.24](/uploads/9873c0814edd9bd330d0e747c9f28e6a/2020-01-16_16.42.24.gif)

#### Solution
Only one drawer is able to be open at a time. If a drawer is opened, it closes the sidebar. If a sidebar is open, it closes the drawer. This allows a user to focus on the task at hand.

title: Save lines_removed and lines_added to database
description:
### Problem to solve

Git's `diff` function calculates "lines deleted" and "lines added" for every commit.  Currently GitLab performs those diffs by either 1) asking Gitaly to do it or 2) using [a Ruby class](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/tree/master/lib/gitlab/diff).  Those options are fine for performing a single diff.  But those require too much processing when you want to diff many commits once, like [for internal metrics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/merge_requests/2120#note_268821747) and [some](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/38062) [analytics](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/12683) [features](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/12079) where code complexity is of interest.

### Proposal

Store `deleted_lines` and `added_lines` in the `merge_request_metrics` table (where `diff_size`, `modified_paths_size`, and `commits_count` are already stored).

Note: There is some [early support](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-data/analytics/merge_requests/2120#note_269101000) for this idea.

### Technical notes

- To see existing usage in the app, look for `deleted_lines` and `added_lines` in Ruby and `deletedLines` and `addedLines` in JS.

title: XSS vulnerability on custom project templates form
description:
### Summary

The "custom project templates" form is vulnerable to Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack, as originally reported by  @jbroullon in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security/gitlab/merge_requests/50#note_271210097.

### Steps to reproduce

- Log in as an admin
- Add a malicious script to a group name
   - Open any group
   - Select Settings > General in the left sidebar
   - Add this to the "Group name": `<SCRIPT>alert('ATTACKED!')</SCRIPT>`
   - Click to "Save changes"
- Confirm the malicious script is executed on the "Custom project templates" page
   - Go to Settings > Custom project templates
   - Click the group search dropdown input to open it
   - See an alert appear with the text "ATTACKED!"

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

User input __is__ treated as trusted.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

User input is __not__ treated as trusted.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Similar to #30173 and #197301.

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

- Escape using [`sanitizeItem()`](https://dev.gitlab.org/gitlab/gitlabhq/merge_requests/3553/diffs#42837bd6b8bd274818be949cdd3fc9c0f3b580f8_50_52)
- Escape before saving to the database (but there is [strange behavior with this](https://dev.gitlab.org/gitlab/gitlabhq/merge_requests/3553))

title: XSS vulnerability in admin feature to send email notification
description:
### Summary

The `/admin/email` endpoint is vulnerable to Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack, as originally reported by  @jbroullon in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security/gitlab/merge_requests/50#note_271320217.

### Steps to reproduce

- Log in as an admin
- Add a malicious script to a group name
   - Open any group
   - Select Settings > General in the left sidebar
   - Add this to the "Group name": `<SCRIPT>alert('ATTACKED!')</SCRIPT>`
   - Click to "Save changes"
- Confirm the malicious script is executed on the "Send email notification" page
   - Go to /admin/email
   - Click the "Recipient group" dropdown input to open it
   - See an alert appear with the text "ATTACKED!"

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

User input __is__ treated as trusted.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

User input is __not__ treated as trusted.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Similar to #30173 and #197302.

![Screen_Shot_2020-01-14_at_2.45.46_PM](/uploads/b95293b6a37101e7441895d254aa516a/Screen_Shot_2020-01-14_at_2.45.46_PM.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

- Escape using [`sanitizeItem()`](https://dev.gitlab.org/gitlab/gitlabhq/merge_requests/3553/diffs#42837bd6b8bd274818be949cdd3fc9c0f3b580f8_50_52)
- Escape before saving to the database (but there is [strange behavior with this](https://dev.gitlab.org/gitlab/gitlabhq/merge_requests/3553))

title: Allow group owners to reset 2FA/MFA for Group Managed Accounts
description:
### Problem to solve

Resetting two-factor authentication (2FA - sometimes known as multi-factor authentication or MFA) on GitLab.com today involves opening a ticket with GitLab support, and having a validated member of the customer's userbase "vouch" for the identity of the requestor. For our customers with large numbers of users, this can be a fairly common need.

Allowing group owners the ability to reset 2FA for members of the group would speed up this process and remove some of the ticket load from support.

### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ -->
* Persona: [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* GitLab.com Group Owners

### Proposal

NOTE: Since GMA is not a concept we're investing in at the moment an alternative approach to this issue will be covered here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225767

When a Group Managed Account is locked-out due to a loss of their second-factor device, a Group Owner should be able to "reset" 2FA and provide the locked-out user with a way to re-pair with their second-factor device.

We could add a `Disable` button only visible to Group Owners on the members list, which is similar to how we handle it for Self-Managed Administrators:

![Screenshot_2020-03-30_at_7.15.05_PM](/uploads/5ae940d5b0c145228ef9766bc7b9ee02/Screenshot_2020-03-30_at_7.15.05_PM.png)

### Permissions and Security

`Group Owners` should be the role with access to this feature.

<!-- ### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature-change-workflow.html

### Testing

See the test engineering process for further help: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/ -->

### What is the type of buyer? 

All .com customers that enable Group Managed Accounts (Silver/Gold).

title: Add new usage ping counter for `events`
description:
As part of usage ping, I would want to know how many users are creating events (https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/events.html)

Currently, there is no good way in usage ping to deduct the total number of active users on an instance. The `active_users` number is really just the total non-blocked account count so it's not actually measuring "activity". 

Adding `events` as a time-bounded counter to usage ping would give us a good proxy for how many users are actually active on every instance sending usage ping.

cc: @sid_reddy @a_akgun

title: Add ability to dismiss a notification broadcast message for a user
description:
Follow-up on https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/engineering/issues/2601

The new notification messages overlap the content of GitLab. We therefore want to have a way to dismiss those messages.
Using a cookie to save that a message should be hidden is enough for now.

title: Display issue created in vulnerability list with dynamic issue status icon
description:
### Problem to solve

Today we display the issue created icon when an issue has been created from a vulnerability. This was done due to our inability to get the status of the issue (open/closed) and render it in the list. 

#213742 will provide the GraphQL endpoints on the ~backend necessary to display issue status.  This issue represents the ~frontend work to display the link to the issue along with the correct icon representing it's status.

title: Re-factor Analytics Controller to separate out promotions path
description:
## Summary

<!--
Please briefly describe what part of the code base needs to be refactored.
-->

(This is a follow-up issue from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security/gitlab/merge_requests/58)

[The Analytics Controller](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/controllers/groups/analytics_controller.rb#L30) checks if promotions are on before choosing what is rendered.

The same check is done in a couple other places:
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/helpers/ee/groups_helper.rb#L68
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/views/groups/analytics/show.html.haml#L69

We want to re-factor the code, by creating a new controller action (eg. `promotion`) with a `before_action` that redirects to `promotion_path` if `show_promotions?` is true.

title: Correlate child pipeline to triggering job (UX improvement)
description:
<!-- The first four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

## Problem to solve

> As a user, I want to understand which job triggers a child pipeline, so I can understand the progression of the pipeline.

All child pipelines have the same appearance and there is no information that can link back to the job triggering them. 

The user needs to expand the child pipeline and look at the jobs in it to understand what the pipeline is about.

| Screenshot of pipeline with multiple child pipelines, not easy to know which jobs triggered which child pipeline |
| --- |
| ![image](/uploads/5b2954be74b9f6a0227735029cfc2108/image.png) |

## Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

## User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses? 
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ --> 

## Proposal

Create a visual link between the trigger job and the child pipeline.

1. When a user hovers on a job that is a bridge job, visually highlight the linked downstream pipeline
2. When user hovers on a downstream/child pipeline, visually highlight the trigger job in the parent pipeline
3. Change the display name of the child and downstream pipelines to 'Child Pipeline <#ID>' or 'Project name <#ID>', respectively to make the relation clearer
4. On hover 
   • For bridge jobs, shown the information about the pipeline that it triggers in the tooltip
   • For child/downstream pipelines, show the information about the job that triggers it
(Designs are attached to the issue)

## Further details

<!-- Include use cases, benefits, goals, or any other details that will help us understand the problem better. -->

For a future iteration, we can address in a separate issue this proposed approach from [comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/197140#note_306946790):

To visualize which job created a specific child pipeline, instead of using labels we could enhance the display name of the downstream (child or multi-project) pipeline:

* Today is in the form like `gitlab • #86` (project + pipeline ID)
* A great improvement would be adding more context like `test/docs ▶ gitlab • #86` where `test` and `docs` are respectively the stage and job name of the trigger job that created the downstream pipeline.

title: Using the Web IDE Web Terminal leads to error 500 when accessing the dashboard/projects list
description:
### Summary

Using the Web IDE Web Terminal leads to error 500 when accessing the dashboard/projects list.

### More info

The problem was revealed by `qa/specs/features/ee/browser_ui/3_create/web_ide/web_terminal_spec.rb`. It passed but caused subsequent tests to fail.

To reproduce the error on GDK I ran the test via:

```
$ cd qa
$ bin/qa Test::Instance::All http://localhost:3000 -- qa/specs/features/ee/browser_ui/3_create/web_ide/web_terminal_spec.rb --tag quarantine
```

And then I see `undefined method `detailed_status' for nil:NilClass` when I try to navigate to the dashboard or projects list.

The error goes away when I delete the pipeline that runs the web terminal.

I reproduced it using a docker executor and docker runner (same as the test uses), but I don't know if it can also be reproduced with other executors.

### Steps to reproduce

1. [Configure a runner to allow a web terminal to run](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/web_ide/index.html#runner-configuration):

```toml
concurrent = 1

[session_server]
  listen_address = "0.0.0.0:8093"
  advertise_address = "localhost:8093"
  session_timeout = 120
```

2. Register the runner to a project.
3. [Add `.gitlab/.gitlab-webide.yml` so that it can run the terminal](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/web_ide/index.html#web-ide-configuration-file):

```yaml
terminal:
  script: sleep 60
```

4. Start the web terminal.
5. Try to load GitLab's dashboard.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

`undefined method 'detailed_status' for nil:NilClass`

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The dashboard/projects list loads.

title: Handle GraphQL exposed fields and types behind feature flags
description:
As we continue to develop our GraphQL API, we're going to have to deal with how feature flags integrate with GraphQL declarations.

We should be able to selectively hide fields and types behind a feature flag.

the `graphql-ruby` gem has a method [`visible?`](https://graphql-ruby.org/authorization/visibility.html) that we can use to selectively hide exposed fields and types behind feature flags.

@seanarnold has suggested this kind of declaration:

```ruby
field :test_field, type: GraphQL::STRING_TYPE, 
      null: false,
      description: 'Some test field',
      feature_key: :some_feature_key
```

Ensure that docs are identical regardless of whether the FF is on or off.

title: Create Vue Alert wrapper around GlAlert
Restrict Access-Control-Expose-Headers by API endpoint
description:
## Summary

!22838 addressed #194897, added missing headers to `Access-Control-Expose-Headers`. The headers themselves were already included in the response, so the data itself has been going out across many different requests. In reviewing the MR for ~security, @dcouture [agreed](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22838#note_272139225) that we'd like to ultimately see this limited to only the applicable API endpoints.

title: Group repository contributors by email
description: If a users (Author) name changes in the git config the contribution count becomes split. eg Author Name: Jane Bloggs email abc.com, Author name: Jane Doe email: abc.com. Same person, same account and email but 2 entries in the contributors chart for the repo. Can this / Should this be grouped by account and email instead of Author Name? refers to page /graphs/develop 'repository > contributors'

title: Make `RepositoryLinkFilter` handle Gitaly failures gracefully
description:
`RepositoryLinkFilter` processes relative links and turns them into links to files in a repository / wiki.

When Gitaly is down / degraded, Markdown post-processing fails / times out because this filter depends on Gitaly.

I think we should be able to handle this gracefully and just leave the possible repository links unchanged.

title: SAST: Variable SAST_EXCLUDED_PATHS is not respected
description:
### Summary While setting up SAST for Gitaly, I noticed that the directories and files specified in `SAST_EXCLUDED_PATHS` are not excluded from the results. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a new branch on Gitaly and edit [`.gitlab-ci.yml`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml) with below snippet to enable SAST: ```yaml include: - template: SAST.gitlab-ci.yml variables: SAST_DISABLE_DIND: "true" SAST_EXCLUDED_PATHS: "config.toml.example" SAST_DEFAULT_ANALYZERS: "gosec, secrets" gosec-sast: before_script: - apk add pkgconfig libgit2-dev gcc libc-dev ``` 2. Push your branch to run the SAST job. 3. Open an MR and inspect the results reported by the SAST job. Note that there are results for the excluded file `config.toml.example`. ### What is the current *bug* behavior? The MR widget does include findings for folders and files listed in `SAST_EXCLUDED_PATHS`. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The MR widget and Security Dashboard do NOT include findings for folders and files listed in `SAST_EXCLUDED_PATHS`. ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info

title: Refactor Apollo cache updates to be immutable in Design Management application
description:
## Summary

In Apollo 2.6 a few new options were provided (namely, `assumeImmutableResults`, `freezeResults`, and `returnPartialData`) for rendering components faster and more smoothly.

While Apollo Client cannot mandate immutable data processing for all application code that consumes cache results, it can reward us for writing our code in an immutable style. In Apollo Client 2.6, if we’re confident that the application code does not modify cache result objects, we can unlock substantial performance improvements by communicating this assumption to the ApolloClient constructor via passing `assumeImmutableResults: true`. So far we don't have a lot of mutations in GitLab's codebase but our usage of GraphQL is growing and it's better to leverage the immutability now, rather than rewrite updates later.

More to say, in Apollo Client 3.0, authors intend to make both `freezeResults` and `assumeImmutableResults` true by default (meaning we would need to make this work to upgrade anyway).

## Improvements

We can gain slight performance improvements right now (considering the fact we have just a few mutations) and we can stick to this 'more performant' strategy while our GraphQL codebase grows.

## Risks

There are no significant risks as the updates logic won't change: the result is going to be the same
```javascript
myArray.push(1)
// the code below will provide the same result
myArray = [...myArray, 1]
```

However, we need to be careful when enabling `assumeImmutableResults` and `freezeResults` and check with console errors that we _really_ have an immutable update. Otherwise the UI won't update.


## Involved components

`ee/app/assets/javascripts/design_management/utils/cache_update.js`

title: Geo: Document on the "replicable DSL"
description:
Started from the [discussion](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2161#note_270685444) (and onward).

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2161 we should have technical docs on our "replicable DSL", which was initially implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/23447.

### Definition of done

What we need to complete this issue:

* Decide on naming: In the POCs we've working on in the epic we've been raising different things like "replicable", "strategy", "geo_trackable", and what not. We need to clearly state what is what. Like a model connected to a git repo, which of both is the "replicable", or is it even something else?
* Decide on the DSL itself: When naming is clear, we can decide how a GitLab developer specify what and how Geo should replicate something.

title: Comments on Epics do not show on User's activity feeds
description:
## Release notes

The goal of this issue is to increase parity to issues and allow the users of epics to have their activity recorded while working on an epic.

Please see the [parent epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4676) to see the other MVCs that bring epics to parity with issues.

### Problem to solve 

> When collaborating on priority work items, I want to understand which items my team or I have iterated with, so that I may better keep track of discussions that need my attention.

Creating, managing, and interacting with Epics does not create a note on the user activity page.  In the worst case scenarios this causes anxiety for users by thinking they may not have created an Epic properly, or making it more difficult to find their recent comments.  

### Intended users


* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)

### User experience goal

- There is parity between the way Epics and other similar objects like Issues behave. 
- Users can interact with user activity pages to get breadcrumbs on Epics they or others have created or interacted with.


### Proposal

Any interaction with Epics creates a note on the activity page. This should follow the same logic as Issues.

IE:

| New epic | Epic comment | Epic closure |
| ------ | ------ | ------ |
| ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/d28d989d45e1d1e879e45bed8f4334a0/image.png) | ![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/7eac1df8af335f943071ef6505fcda02/image.png)|![image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/e73b6d1d7bac6364660ac2681788d281/image.png)|

title: Make Debian slim the base image for Dependency Scanning for Python
description:
### Problem to solve

Currently the Docker image used to perform Dependency Scanning on Python projects is based on [Alpine Linux](https://www.alpinelinux.org/) but this base Docker image is not [manylinux2010](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0571/#the-manylinux2010-policy) compatible, and many Python dependencies cannot be installed, which makes Dependency Scanning fail. Switching to [Debian slim](https://www.debian.org) would make solve this, and make the scanner support more Python projects. See [conclusion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13694#conclusion) of preliminary study.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)


### Further details

Dependency Scanning for Python is implemented in the [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python) project. It is available as Docker image, and [its base image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/blob/v2.6.0/Dockerfile#L1) is `python:3.6-alpine`. Alpine Linux is not [manylinux2010](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0571/#the-manylinux2010-policy) compatible, and many Python wheels cannot be installed. Switching to Debian makes possible to install packages like `Pillow` using `manylinux1_x86_64` binary wheels. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13694#note_222160347

The official Debian image is much bigger than Linux Alpine. The slim variant of Debian is also bigger than Linux Alpine, but the difference is less than 100 MB.

The installation of Python packages is needed for Python projects having no supported dependency lock file. For instance, it is required when the Python project uses pip, and the pip requirements file is not a lock file.
### Proposal

Change the base image of [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python) to Debian Slim. The change would result in the 250 MB Docker image, compared to the 170 MB for the Alpine based image. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/merge_requests/37#note_263938092

This has already been implemented in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/merge_requests/37

### Permissions and Security

Same

### Documentation

None

### Testing

Add `Pillow` dependency to Python test projects used for QA, to prove manylinux compatibility.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

GitLab Dependency Scanning can scan most Python projects (if versions of Python and pip are compatible), and doesn't break because it cannot install a broadly used Python package.

### What is the type of buyer? 

~"GitLab Ultimate" 

### Links / references

See [conclusion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13694#conclusion) of preliminary study.

See https://pythonspeed.com/articles/base-image-python-docker-images/

/cc @NicoleSchwartz @gonzoyumo

epic.title: Improve Dependency Scanning support for Python

title: Allow to fetch incoming emails from multiple addresses
description:
### Problem to solve

This is prerequisite for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/2201.

By default we use single email address for all incoming emails (configured in config/gilab.yml's `incoming_email` section) and has format `incoming+%{key}@gitlab.com`. And types of emails (e.g. comments, new issues, service desk issues) are identified depending on the key pattern.

The problem is that for service desk emails this address with the key is quite long and not easily readable - it looks like this: `incoming+<group>-<project>-<project id>-issue-@gitlab.com` and it would be nice to use simpler and configurable address for it.

### Proposal

Add a separate configurable service desk email section into config/gitlab.yml which would allow to customize service desk email address pattern similar to `incoming_email` section we already have:

```
  service_desk_email:
    enabled: true

    # The email address including the `%{key}` placeholder that will be replaced to reference the item being replied to.
    # The placeholder can be omitted but if present, it must appear in the "user" part of the address (before the `@`).
    address: "support+%{key}@gmail.com"

    # Email account username
    # With third party providers, this is usually the full email address.
    # With self-hosted email servers, this is usually the user part of the email address.
    user: "user@gmail.com"
    # Email account password
    password: "password"

    # IMAP server host
    host: "imap.gmail.com"
    # IMAP server port
    port: 993
    # Whether the IMAP server uses SSL
    ssl: true
    # Whether the IMAP server uses StartTLS
    start_tls: false

```

Our mail_room's configuration will be configured to fetch emails from both `incoming_email` and `service_desk_email` (if these are enabled - by default service_desk_email will be disabled).

Emails delivered to `service_desk_email` will be enqueued in a separate service desk queue/worker (not the default `app/workers/email_receiver_worker.rb`) and this service desk worker will process `key` part of the email (this could be perhaps project's full path name? :thinking: ). So for example if emails is delivered to `support+gitlab-org/gitlab@gitlab.com`, it will extract project from the part after `+` - same as we do for other incoming emails, the difference is that we don't need too complicated pattern after `+` because we already know this is a service desk email based the separate address before `+` - `support+...@gitlab.com`. The pattern of the key will be `project_slug-configurable_name` - for example for `gitlab` project it would be `gitlab-org-gitlab-configurable_name`.

Then in the next step - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/2201 - we can make the `+{key}` configurable.

We will probably have to update also omnibus configuration to pre-generate this new config section in gitlab.yml. And also update gdk with this default config.

title: Follow-up from "Add Is using seat badge to admin user overview"
Bulk edit iterations on issues within groups and projects
description:
## Problem to solve

Given there are now iterations, issue lists should support bulk editing iterations. 

## Proposal

1. You should be able to bulk edit `Iteration`

![Issue list bulk edit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/0dcae3640599d2b95a92b465cdc785da/Screen_Shot_2020-01-10_at_10.18.39_AM.png)

## Context

This is a follow on from the initial MVC for adding iterations - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/35290e

### Release notes

Instead of having to manually update the iteration on issues one at a time, iterations can now be bulk updated from the issue list of a group or project.

title: Scope Board To Current Iteration
description:
## Problem

I can't scope a Board to the current Iteration...which pretty much means I have to pick between using Iterations and not using Boards...or sticking with using Milestones instead of adopting Iterations (which is what I really want to do)

## Proposal

- Within configuration modal for a Board, expose the ability to scope the Board to the current Iteration.
- Current is defined as the current timestamp falls within the Start and End dates of a given Iteration.
- Based on the design of Iterations, there should only ever be one current Iteration.  

## UX

![MVC](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/cac3eb91949da4a6ca2fd9b33ff4f81f/Screen_Shot_2020-09-16_at_5.06.39_PM.png)

## Acceptance

- [ ] Pajamas First
- [ ] GraphQL First
- [ ] When the "scope to current iteration" is active, the Board will only show Issues that are part of the current Iteration.

## Context

This is a follow on from the initial MVC for adding Iterations as a type of Timebox - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/35290

## Design resources
* [Mural board](https://app.mural.co/invitation/mural/gitlab2474/1597848880369?sender=hreynolds8958&key=0cf30769-96a0-4a7f-bef4-23eafc60ac78)

## Availability and Testing

Ensure test coverage in unit/integration tests.

### Release Notes

Many teams use Boards to manage issues during an Iteration. In 13.6, we added support for [filtering issues on a Board to a specific Iteration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/118742), but it is cumbersome to remember to apply that filter every time you go to your Board. In this release, we've added the ability to scope your Board to the currently active Iteration.

![scope-board-to-iteration](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/47e9d6b95cfa490a3d79cee8302eee5b/Screen_Shot_2020-12-17_at_10.12.52_AM.png)

https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/issue_board.html#configurable-issue-boards

title: Experiment with making the phone number field optional within SaaS trial sign up
description:
## Hypothesis
We believe that by making the phone number field optional in the SaaS trial sign up we will increase the trial creation rate and increase the total IACV generated from trials. 
 
## Business problem
The required phone number field is only as valuable as the data that it collects and based on our analysis 77.8% of the time it is not providing the business with any value due to fake phone number submissions while reducing the trial conversion rate by up to 5%. 
 
## Supporting data
It is a common industry understanding that requiring a phone number field during a form submission reduces the submission rate. Unbounce indicates that on average it reduces form conversions by 5% ([source](https://unbounce.com/conversion-rate-optimization/how-to-optimize-contact-forms/)). By requiring a non-validated phone number field we're reducing our form conversion rate without the added benefit of a valid phone number for the sales team. 
 
I analyzed the most recent 1,000 submissions to the trial form and found that 77.8% of the phone number submitted were fake. I defined "fake" in this analysis as any phone number with less than 7 digits or highly visible pattern i.e. 1234567 or 1231234 etc. 
  
## Expected outcome
By making the phone number field optional field we believe that we will increase the trial creation rate by 3% and generate more IACV than the control group.
 
## Experiment design & implementation
We will run a 50/50 experiment where 50% of users (control group) will get the standard trial sign up form where the phone number field is required and 50% of users (experiment group) will get a trial sign up form where the phone number field will be optional. 
 
We will measure the trial sign up rates between the control and experiment groups. We will then monitor the trial upgrade rates within 45 days of the trial start date for both the control and experiment groups. 

| Base | Variant |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![MBP-13-viewport-trialFlow--current](/uploads/66e864cb3106e8470044ef8210529db5/MBP-13-viewport-trialFlow--current.jpg) | ![MBP-13-viewport-trialFlow--optionalPhoneField](/uploads/e60802cd1bd99442d590113c345fd43c/MBP-13-viewport-trialFlow--optionalPhoneField.jpg)|
| Current version of https://gitlab.com/-/trials/new | Variant with optional phone number field | 
 
## ICE score

| Impact | Confidence | Ease | Score |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| 8 |  7 |  9 | 8 |
 
## Known assumptions
We don't know the actual increase in the trial creation rate we will see by making the phone number field optional, 3% was an estimate based on Unbounce analysis where they saw a 5% increase when the phone number field was removed. 
 
While we know that 77.8% of the phone numbers submitted are fake. The remaining 22.2% could represent a meaningful amount of revenue by running this as a 50/50 experiment we will be able to understand the revenue impact. 
 
This experiment is limited to the SaaS trial form and a second test would need to be run to validate if the results are consistent with the self-hosted trial form. 
 
## Results, lessons learned, next steps
(to be filled out when the experiment is completed and results are analyzed


## Cleanup

- Cleanup the feature flag  and specs https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/24449#note_327281459

title: New re-usable component for Blob File Content
description:
Technical discover: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196712#note_271152500

Relevant for at least the following components:

| View | Screenshot |
|------|------------|
| Snippet | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.28.34](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/f051bcfdefddb618523f8dc98b2b9765/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.28.34.png) |
| File | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.28.05](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/328619ac78d3b4d4682ea2e6d0e30034/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.28.05.png) |
| Diff | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.27.41](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/025d9e8d581004491233701eb814dcaf/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_12.27.41.png) |

However, the way we present information in Diff, even though might look similar, is technically completely different under the hood. Existing `app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_content.vue` component is much more complex than needed for Snippets and Files. It is very tightly coupled with the functionality of the Diffs to the point of being not-practical and irresponsible to make it work for Snippets and Files. However, since we have at least two places that would benefit from rendering the blob in the same manner, it makes sense to generalize it and abstract it into a new component.

**:question: A candidate for gitlab-ui component?**

Doesn't make a lot of sense

**:muscle: Reusability scenario suggestion**:

* New `shared` component in GitLab itself.
* Why not to re-use `app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_content.vue` as suggested by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/34822? See [relevant part of the technical discovery](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196712#note_271152619).

title: New re-usable component for Blob File Header
description:
Technical discover: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196712#note_271152337

The main candidates for this component to be re-used between:

| View | Screenshot |
|------|------------|
| Snippet | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.49.56](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/0c26fd90bb75193d025c87aa8b223f07/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.49.56.png) |
| File | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.50.33](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/c640c1392d691f8426889e70efbdf710/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.50.33.png) |
| Diff | ![Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.50.09](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/31cb2b59a493d1cefae1c5a33f5de841/Screenshot_2020-01-14_at_11.50.09.png) |
| etc. |  |

From the screenshots, it's obvious that Snippet's File header component has much more common with the File header than Diff. The File header in Diff View adds additional functionality, is already an existing component tightly coupled with the matter of diffing. I assume, there might be other use cases for this component so it might be a good candidate for re-usability as well.

**:question: A candidate for gitlab-ui component?**

The component is very connected to the way we present information in GitLab, so I don't think this is a good candidate for *gitlab-ui*.

**:muscle: Reusability scenario suggestion**:

* New `shared` component in GitLab itself with slots for filling in content. Preferably with the control of used components for the buttons on the right to make the look consistent.
* Why not to re-use `app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_file_header.vue` as suggested by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/34822?  See [relevant part of the technical discovery](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/196712#note_271152619).

title: Redeploying to a stopped environment does not transition the environment back to active
description:
### Summary

After manually stopping the environment, it doesn't go back to "active" after running new pipeline deploying it.

### Steps to reproduce

1. create a new project with this `.gitlab-ci.yml`:
    ```yaml
    start:
      script:
        - echo "start test"
      environment:
        name: production
        url: example.com
        on_stop: stop
    
    stop:
      script:
        - echo "stop"
      when: manual
      environment:
        name: production
        action: stop
    ```
1. wait for pipeline to finish
1. go to environments
1. press `stop` button
1. wait for stop action to finish
1. re-run the pipeline and wait for it's completion
1. visit the environments page

Here's the test project: https://gitlab.com/vshushlin/test-restart-environment

Pressing "Re-deploy the environment" from the environments view also doesn't help.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Despite redeployment, the environment still shows as stopped.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

When a deployment occurs, it could be spinning up hardware resources, etc. Therefore, the environment should show as active.

#### Affects Version

GitLab.com (14.4)

title: Service model: Rename template attribute to instance
description:
### Problem to solve

As part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/2137, *Service templates* will become service instance-level configuration.

### Proposal

To better reflect and capture the new domain design, we have to rename the `Service#template` to `Service#instance` in the backend.
