title: Document common issues causing nondeterministic E2E tests
description:
### Problem to solve

E2E tests have a higher risk of being nondeterministic (flaky) and is an ongoing issue for our tests. Currently, we do not have insight into the reasons for nondeterminism, so we may be repeatedly introducing flakiness by following the same old patterns.

### Further details

### Proposal

1. Create an issue catalog (in the handbook) of common underlying problems that introduce flakiness for SET education.
1. Include grooming of this catalog with every flaky test fix, i.e., determine reason for the current flaky test and add or update the catalog if appropriate.

### Who can address the issue

Everyone who writes and fixes automated E2E tests.

epic.title: QA Framework Changes that improves efficiency

title: Enable container_expiration_policies with Graphql
description:
~"backend-weight::2" 

## Overview

This is the initial step in [enabling Graphql for the package stage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/37474).

The [project api](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/projects.html#edit-project) is currently set up to allow creation and updating of a given project's `container_expiration_policy`. The goal of this issue is to expand that same functionality to the [graphql project api](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#project).

There are possibly two steps here:

1. Enable the project graphql resource to allow `container_expiration_policy`
1. Migrate the front end to use graphql instead of the rest API

## References

* Graphql: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/api_graphql_styleguide.html
* Project Graphql API: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/api/graphql/reference/index.html#project
* Project Rest API: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/37474
* Originating comment: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/37474#note_270996435

epic.title: Migrate packages backend to use graphql

title: Render related issue(s) on standalone vulnerability page
description:
### Problem to solve

We want to create issues from standalone vulnerabilities in #196767 we also need to render a reference to those issues back on the page like we do on the current security dashboard.

### Intended users

* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Further details
![](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/f7de895e6f33dcba35fa0b90edba2846/with-issue.png)

### Proposal
If there are related issues we should render them as per the above design.

We can very likely reuse the component on the current security dashboard modal.

### Documentation

Since this page is hidden behind a feature flag, we do not need documentation at this stage.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
We will need to:

- [ ] Show all the related issues on a vulnerability
- [ ] Show all the information hilighted in the designs
- [ ] Have feature parity with the current implementation in the security dashboard widget.

title: Add ability to create an issue from a standalone vulnerability (Frontend)
description:
### Problem to solve

We need to be able to create an issue from a standalone vulnerability page.

The ~backend functionality for this is tracked here #34564

### Intended users

* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)

### Proposal

We need to add a "create issue" button in the top corner (as per the [designs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13561#vulnerability-cases)). This button, when pressed, needs to make a call to the API to create a new issue and associate it with that vulnerability. The user should then be taken to that newly created issue.

Eventually we will need to display the related issue on the vulnerability page, but that's outside the scope of this issue.


### Documentation

No documentation will be required at this stage as the entire page is hidden behind a feature flag.


### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
We should be able to create a linked issue from a vulnerability.

### Links / references

title: Drop database tables related to Code Analytics feature

title: Instance Security Dashboard displays incomplete error message when failing to add projects
description:
### Summary

A user may not have sufficient rights to add certain projects to the Instance Security Dashboard. When this happens, a message should be displayed saying which project(s) couldn't be added.

At the moment, that message only says "Unable to add".

### Steps to reproduce

1. Go to https://staging.gitlab.com/-/security
1. Click "Edit dashboard"
1. Search for `gitlab-foss`
1. Click the first result
1. Click "Add projects"
1. Observe error message

### Example Project

See reproduction steps. I'm not sure what the criteria are for what allows a user to add a project to the dashboard, but at least @markrian on staging cannot add the project with id `13083`.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Error message says "Unable to add"

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Error message says "Unable to add gitlab-foss", or perhaps "Unable to add gitlab-org/gitlab-foss"

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2020-01-14_Security_Dashboard](/uploads/02dbecba8bdf002fd0f1b554a1279d01/Screenshot_2020-01-14_Security_Dashboard.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

The message is generated in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/v12.6.3-ee/ee/app/assets/javascripts/security_dashboard/store/modules/project_selector/actions.js#L76.

title: Add vulnerability status text to the standalone vulnerability page
description:
Currently the standalone vulnerability page displays `Detected [timeago] in pipeline [id]`, regardless of the status of the vulnerability.

The [designs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13561#vulnerability-page-states) require that this message changes depending on the status.

| Status | Message |
| ------ | ------ |
| Detected | `Detected [timeago] in pipeline [id]` |
| Confirmed | `Confirmed [timeago] by [author]` | 
| Dismissed | `Dismissed [timeago] by [author]` | 
| Resolved | `Resolved [timeago] by [author]` | 

*Note:* This is currently in HAML but for increased interactivity, it may be better to add this to the Vue app created in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/38123

title: [Feature flag] Enable user association deletion in batches
description:
## What

Remove the `:destroy_user_associations_in_batches` feature flag.

## Owners

- Team: Create::Editor
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_create_editor`
- Best individual to reach out to: Francisco Javier López

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

When a user is deleted through `Users::DestroyService` the user associations will be deleted in batches.

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

The user is not deleted.

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

Sentry

## Roll Out Steps

- [x] Enable on staging
- [x] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour
- [x] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with `#production` and `#g_delivery` on slack.
- [x] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [x] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production`
- [x] Cross post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

title: Expose count of all sub-epics and issues in epic tree
description:
A follow-up from this discussion: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22284#note_270633407

In the epic-tree widget, we currently show only numbers of open/closed sub-epics and issues which user can see. The problem is that this gives inaccurate overall status about completeness of the epic. For this reason we should show counts of all open/closed sub-epics/issues there, even if it means we expose existence (only existence, no additional details) if a private/confidential  sub-epic/issue.

Setting weight 2 because this is quite easy change and assigning to myself because I'm familiar with the original query I introduced in 12.6.

/cc @johnhope

title: Technical Discovery for Snippet View refactoring to Vue
description:
## [Original technical discovery](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/32060#note_232253731)
[Original discovery](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/32060#note_232253731) by @pslaughter

### Scope

**Snippet edit page:**

From the frontend, the edit page can remain the same - a new edit simply adds a new version on the backend. Thanks backend! :smile:

**Snippet show page:**

* [User snippets (FE entrypoint)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/412f62919340e5df7505749927202bf6ea8b3785/app/views/snippets/show.html.haml#L11)
* [Project snippets (FE entrypoint)](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/7f15dacb5504b0ba7f9eb73e8a60e494e3473274/app/views/projects/snippets/show.html.haml#L10)

This is the only page we'll consider at the moment since it's the only one requiring upcoming changes.

### New functionality (versioned snippets) components

At it's simplest implementation, versioned snippets will require the following UI components (whether implemented in HAML or Vue):

* Tabs
* Revision list

For page load performance, we should avoid loading all the data at once, which requires that some scripting is necessary. Migrating to Vue can make implementing these new features more efficient and reliable, while staying in HAML + Vanilla JS can make things difficult to test and maintain.

### Existing functionality components

So what does migrating to Vue look like? Here's a list of components which compose the current snippets UI:

* Page Header (can be left in HAML)
* Title
* Description
* Embed actions
* File header
* File content
* Comment box

Thankfully there's some preexisting components we can reuse here, making these changes mostly trivial. Some non-trivial components include the file header and content. There's an opportunity of reusing preexisting components here, but it's not perfect.

Another non-trivial piece is loading the extra data that's needed (e.g. snippet previewed content, snippet links, extra meta information). Most of this is already available in the API, but some new fields will probably be needed.

#### Reusability opportunity

It looks like we can easily reuse the existing CSS.

The following components contain **mostly** reusable code, but some will require some refactoring to make reusable for our case:

* [Markdown comment Vue component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/2d94e2c913417c2d1cce1bcc9c0ab4ede97a0d25/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/components/markdown/field.vue#L209)
* [Reaction component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/0c028a816b6d8941b435291f298e1fffaa7b5af0/app/assets/javascripts/notes/components/note_awards_list.vue#L174)
* [Use of clipboard in Vue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/e95a6d1bb93e02df57334af2fd06a0c2ee9cf2dc/app/assets/javascripts/vue_shared/components/modal_copy_button.vue#L70)
* File component:
  * [`app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_content.vue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/5d31e16e808bff9cc101422e17f3596a5f288461/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_content.vue#L102)
  * [`app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_file_header.vue`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/059461232a12c4bef1a3f5014c5746791010f65a/app/assets/javascripts/diffs/components/diff_file_header.vue#L63)

#### Concerns

There's some crossover with the new file component and MR diffs. We should make sure we do this right and find an abstraction that serves both. I label this as a concern, because this will require some attention.

#### Rest vs. GraphQL

Since we will probably need some more data properties exposed in the API, it's worth evaluating whether now is a good time to migrate to GraphQL. This is especially relevant as the schema for the API will grow in complexity due to the upcoming features.

Cons:

* Extra work involved with unfamiliar area.

Opportunities:

* It's easier to create requests that progressively load the page (i.e. load file heads, and then content). This is because the only work needed is to define the shared schema (not each individual request/response).

Pros:

* Easier full stack collaboration.

#### Proposal

**Should we refactor snippets to GraphQL now?**

I'd like BE to weigh in on GraphQL vs. Rest. From the FE, the immediate costs could outweigh the benefits, but it's possible the long term BE benefits are worth it.

**Should we refactor to Vue now?**

Yes. This will **greatly** help implement the changes being proposed in the versions feature and future features.

#### Proposal

I suggest we do a Vue refactoring (no new features) behind a feature flag in one release. We might need some new data exposed in the API (e.g. rendered snippet content), so if we're planning on also migrating to GraphQL, we should probably do this in one swing to minimize the amount of temporary code.

title: gitlab_subscriptions trial column being nil and false
description:
`GitlabSubscription` contains a `trial` column, which defaults to false. Our model scope searches for `false`, indicating paid subscriptions. It was first introduced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/7885.

However a large number of records have the value `nil`. Currently on production:

* 388206 records have `nil`
* 3323787 records have `false`

`false` seems to be the correct value as it is the default value in database, and our Rails scope checks against `false` too.

We need to find 

1. why `nil` was generated (done: answer in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/23037)
1. Whether those `nil`s should have been `false`. (done: see the update below)

### Update

After some code review in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/23037#note_272226873, here is a second round of summary:

When the feature was first deployed, there were those two cases:

1. Those namespaces in trial created subscription with `trial:nil`
1. Those paid namespaces created subscription with `trial:nil`

I think we need to do an audit to see how `nil` is treated in code.

For case one, we might have accidentally made some trial namespaces as paid namespaces.

For case two, paid namespaces might not be treated as paid (e.g. `UpdateMaxSeatsUsedForGitlabComSubscriptionsWorker` certainly skipped those)

title: Select dashboard properties needed in frontend when fetching the dashboard
description:
The following discussion from !22722 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pslaughter started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/merge_requests/22722#note_270957054): 

    > **issue (non-blocking):** We **try** not to save the entire BE object in the FE because the BE endpoints usually have to serve clients other than the FE, so they are bound to receive extra props which we don't need/want to persist.
    > 
    > One nice way to do this is with [underscore's `pick`](https://underscorejs.org/#pick) :shrug:
    > 
    > ```javascript
    > state.dashboard = {
    >   ..._.pick(dashboard, 'name', 'id', 'loremipsum'),
    >   panel_groups: ...
    > },
    > ```
    > 
    > I label this as non-blocking because I don't want to block anything that depends on this, so let's handle this in a follow up issue :smile:

title: Value Stream Analytics - Custom ordering of stages
description:
### Problem to solve
Since customizable stages need to be reordered after they are added, the elements in the list need to have that ability.

### Further details
- [x] Stages can be dragged / dropped into a new location in the list
- [x] Persist the change - [send a PUT request with the new position](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/13076#note_196331145)
- [x] Reuse [existing behaviour](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ee/issues/12196#note_193729318)

### Links / references

title: Leverage scan object to provide QA test scan duration check for Analyzers
description:
### Problem to solve

We don't track the duration of the analysis for the following projects and it could drastically increase it without being aware of it:

* [x] [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven)
* [x] [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python)
* [x] [bundler-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit)
* [x] [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium)

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/34903 solved this issue by adding the duration check to the integration test stage of each project, however, the above projects were not updated because they don't have an integration test stage.

Once [Add scan object to the Security Reports JSON format](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3140) has been completed (at least, when we have the necessary data in the JSON report), we can leverage this scan object to provide scan duration check for the above projects.

### Intended users

~"devops::secure" team members

### Proposal

To make sure we don't increase analysis duration unintentionally after an update, we need to track it and ensure they stay within a given threshold.

When [Add scan object to the Security Reports JSON format](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues/37123) has been completed, we need to do the following:

1. [x] Introduce a `MAX_SCAN_DURATION_SECONDS` variable to the following `.gitlab-ci.yml` files:
   1. [x] [gemnasium-maven](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-maven/-/blob/482e080adeada62b4b9c3c291e4a1aa49e217724/.gitlab-ci.yml#L4)
   1. [x] [gemnasium-python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/blob/e8d5baf36a80dd1c74417f58b6d0a0c441207c5d/.gitlab-ci.yml#L4)
   1. [x] [bundler-audit](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/blob/2c12f323fd341802859e1cae20ab46c210ee1cb7/.gitlab-ci.yml#L4)
   1. [x] [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/b3d02da107ae8f316711e55991862b66f6341b9c/.gitlab-ci.yml#L5) 
1. [x] Add logic to the following qa template files to determine the scan duration time by using the `scan.start_time` and `scan.end_time` values provided by the scanning report, and ensuring that this value is less than the `MAX_SCAN_DURATION_SECONDS` value:
    1. [x] [Dependency Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-dependency_scanning.yml#L122)
    1. [x] [SAST](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-sast.yml) (blocked by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/33724)
    1. [x] [Secret Detection](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/includes-dev/qa-secret_detection.yml)
1. [x] Remove the [`check analyzer scan duration` and `integration test`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/a3e72f6a9a4c0bb62040fd26374af2012c876f8f/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L70-102) jobs in `includes-dev/analyzer.yml`. Please validate with ~"group::static analysis" first as they currently still use the integration tests for community contributions MR (which can't run downstream QA pipelines): [removal MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/183).
1. [x] Test the following projects to ensure that a scan which exceeds the `MAX_SCAN_DURATION_SECONDS` causes a failure in the downstream qa test:
    1. [x] [Dependency Scanning](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/170)
    1. [x] [SAST](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/179)
    1. [x] [Secret Detection](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/180)

### Documentation

- [x] This should be added as part of our test projects documentation: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/common#security-products-test-projects [MR](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/common/-/merge_requests/25)

### Testing

Try to make the QA fail by running an analysis that gets over the threshold.
SET to look at creating branches, add a `before_script` with a `sleep` command. This should fail as it has exceeded the specified maximum duration.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

QA Pipeline fails when an analysis duration exceeds the allowed variation.

### Note

Duration scan checks not added to DAST and License Scanning as they use a different structure for testing. Container Scanning changed to an integration test structure as well ([more info](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/merge_requests/181#note_467371952)).

title: Replace underscore with lodash for ./app/assets/javascripts/blob
description: Replace all underscore methods with native javascript functions (when possible) or lodash equivalents within the directory listed in the title. If there are no equivalents, please start a conversation on the issue on how to best handle this case and get consensus before moving forward. Before submitting an MR, please make sure all specs pass after switching to use the new functions either in native javascript or lodash.
